I was very daunted about the whole undertaking, knowing, first of all, how almost impossible it is for a white man to write about and to imagine himself into the life of a black woman, all the more so if that woman is a slave.
I think part of a writer's job is to be able to imagine her or himself into the skin of somebody else.
That is normal.
You can't pretend to be a writer if you can't do that, if you're not prepared to try.
But power relations are at play as well.
So it took a lot of bloody cheek to dare this.

If I speak with a character's voice, it is because that character has become so much part of me that I can - I think I have the right then to imagine myself into the skin, into the life, into the dreams, into the experience of the particular character that I've chosen.
And that was the challenge, but I also knew that I owed this one to Philida.
